pages.text: Sterling $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) is an alloy of $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) containing 92.5% by weight of $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) and 7.5% by weight of other metals, usually $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l). The sterling $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) standard has a minimum millesimal fineness of 925.$(p)Fine $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l), for example 99.9% pure $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l), is relatively soft, so $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) is usually alloyed with $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) to increase its hardness and strength. Sterling $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) is prone to tarnishing, and elements other than $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l)

can be used in alloys to reduce tarnishing, as well as casting porosity and firescale. Such elements include germanium, $(l:materials/Zinc)zinc$(/l), $(l:materials/Platinum)platinum$(/l), $(l:materials/Silicon)silicon$(/l), and $(l:materials/Boron)boron$(/l). Recent examples of alloys using these metals include argentium, sterlium, sterilite and silvadium.
